bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, September 8, 1940

div1.p: Kean comments on Truby's paper about his service in Cuba. He feels that Truby's narration is of immense value and fears that most of Reed's papers are lost. He mentions that the University of Virginia is honoring Moran with a dinner.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, September 8, 1940

opener.dateline:
2804 N STREET, N. W.
GEORGETOWN
WASHINGTON, D. C.
Sunday.
Sept. 8th 1940

div1.p:
Your Memo and photographs
were received on the 5th and were
followed in the next mail by
Gen. Trubys sketch of his service
in Cuba during the period of the
1st American intervention 1899-
1902- As he wanted me to return
the U. S. S. with pencil comments I
sat down and read it at once
and made a few notes on the
margins and backs of the pages-
He kept a diary of the Y. F. episode
and I imagine a much fuller
one than my random factual
notes- He also, as he was at the
hospital and much of the time
2
in command of it, was familiar
with many details which never
came to my attention and saw
much more of Reed and the
other members of the Commission
than I did- His narrative is
so of immense value and will
rejoice your soul- He has much
to say of Lazear and values his
contributions to the work of the
Commission (as I do) as next to those
of Reed- It was he that Lazear
asked to look after his papers and
possessions and who took from
Lazears coat pocket, after his
death. The precious little note book
with the records of the infected
mosquitos or in it- By the way
I was talking to Gen. Ireland recently
3
about the disappearance of Reed's
records after his death, and found
that altho. he was in the Surg. Gen's
Office at that time he knew no more
about the matter than I did. It then
occurred to me that Mrs. Walter Reed
might have the precious note book and
other papers; so I wrote to Mrs Reed at
once- A prompt reply came from her
daughter that Mrs Reed had no papers
of her distinguished husband's except
personal letters and not many of these
as she had given many of them away
to friends and libraries- So the mystery
of the Reed papers is still unsolved-

I will see if I can carry out your
request to get a stenog. and dictate
the answers to your questionnaire
paragraph by paragraph. When you
get Truby's sketch however I think that
4
what details I care contribute to
the picture will be much diminished
in importance: tho. I must confess that
I have never seen such a glutton for
details and for work as you are-
The patient industry with which you
persue them fills my rather indolent
soul with wonder and admiration-
The relocation of Camp Lazear is one
of the first fruits of it and I hope
that there may be others-

By the way the Medical Faculty of
the Univ. of Va. are giving a dinner to
Moran on Oct. 24th I hope that you may
be there, Tho. it would be a long way
to come for a dinner-

About my diary I will look over the
vol. covering the Summer of 1900 and
see if there are enough items of value
to warrant copying and will either
extract them or lend you the book if I find
enough to warrant it- I have no recent news
of the proposal invasion of the Y. F. Roll of Honor-
The Surgeon General has an eye on it-
